TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, opened his speech by boasting about the series of questions the Opposition asked today, which apparently the Opposition has concluded was highly effective. As a result of those questions, the Opposition made the great discovery that the reductions of the order of $1 billion to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was referring yesterday were reductions from the forward estimates of expenditure. I have been telling journalists that for about the last two months. I have been telling them that that was the sort of target the Government had and was the base from which the forward estimates figure would be measured. So all the questions the Opposition was asking revealed nothing except an attempt by it to find out what the forward estimates figure was. As I have been doing for the last two months, I refused to give the Opposition that figure.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney has repeated the rather puerile points made during Question Time by way of questions from the Opposition that the actual 1983-84 Budget amounted to $1.2 billion below the figure for the forward estimates of expenditure. As I said during Question Time, it was very much easier to cut into the programs which the Fraser Government presided over during the wild spending spree period in its last desperate year in office than it is to cut into a leaner Budget. Nevertheless, it was not entirely without pain that those cuts were made from forward estimates in our first Budget.

Senator Chaney placed great emphasis on the fact that for the 1984-85 Budget, estimates of outlays were $1.3 billion lower than they were in the forward estimates. Therefore, said Senator Chaney, the effort the Government is making this year is puny and puerile compared to the effort it made last year. Superficially there may be something in that, but in fact there is not. The forward estimates published early in 1984 contained, as do all forward estimates, an estimated deflator. The deflator on which those estimates were based was 9 per cent. I believed at the time that the figure was too high, as did many others. The figure was produced by Treasury, the Secretary of which at that time was Mr Stone. That is not unconnected with what I believe is the fact that that deflator estimate was determined more by ideology than mathematics. It was a wish rather than a measurement and it turned out to be very, very wrong.

When the Budget was finally prepared the deflator estimate had fallen to 6 1/2 per cent, and indications are that that figure will be pretty accurate. The difference between those two figures is 2 1/2 per cent. I acknowledge that the deflator figure is not relevant to all Government outlays. I do not have with me the precise percentage to which it is relevant, but it is relevant to the great majority of Government outlays. If it was applied to all Government outlays, the truth is that those forward estimates published early in 1984, due solely to the over-estimate in the deflator, were about $1.2 billion higher than they ought to have been. I see Senator Messner wrinkling his nose.

That figure is subject to the qualification I made about all outlays being affected by the deflator. I acknowledge that that is not the case but the overwhelming majority are. I calculate that up to $1.2 billion is entirely attributable to the erroneous deflator incorporated in the forward estimates at the time they were prepared. Although, for a reason to which I referred earlier, there has been a significant change since then, it illustrates the point that forward estimates, if there are massive parameter changes, are highly unreliable.

Lest the Opposition should seek refuge in that comment and say that, therefore, the forward estimates produced in 1983 were equally unreliable, there were not massive parameter changes between those assumed in the 1983 forward estimates and the actual outturn. In 1983-84 any error it may have contained would have been slight and any error attributable to an incorrect deflator having been built into the model of the estimates was trivial. In 1984 the situation was very different. A deflator of 9 per cent had been built into the estimates, when the final outcome in the Budget estimates was 6 1/2 per cent.

I do not know whether, having been enlightened in that respect, Senator Chaney now wants to castigate the Government for not being rigorous enough in pruning expenditure last year, but he cannot have it both ways. This year the deflator built into the forward estimates, principally because of Mr Stone's retirement as Secretary to the Treasury, is a far more credible figure. I am not going to tell honourable senators what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is credible.

—But it is credible. It was credible at the time it was produced, in my judgment, as the one produced in 1984 was not credible, in my judgment. The one produced this year was credible. If it needs any revision, because of the devaluation, the required revision might well be upward.

SPEECH.PARA: The actual outcomes and the forward estimates this year, as in 1983, are not likely to be substantially affected by changes in the deflator. The $1 billion reduction which the Prime Minister forecast yesterday, which I have been talking about for a couple of months, and which will be announced next month, is the outcome of adjustments to programs and real expenditures, not to parameter changes.

In the 1984-85 forward estimates, published early in 1984, the changes in the outlays outcome and the forecasts were overwhelmingly due to the changed parameters. Parameter changes will not be related to any significant degree at all to the $1 billion reduction which will be announced next month. They are attributable to adjustments to programs. That is in marked contrast to the much vaunted Fraser Government's razor gang of 1981, which laboured for some months in a blaze of publicity about the ruthless razor gang getting stuck into the fat of Government. The Review of Commonwealth Functions Committee ultimately produced a booklet entitled 'Ministerial Statement-Review of Commonwealth Functions', which does not have in it one figure quantifying an actual reduction in programs; not one single figure quantifying the massive and ruthless attack on bloated government expenditure which that Committee claimed to have made. There was a global figure given by the Prime Minister of the day, who said:

Compared with the costs of continuing programs on the basis of existing policies and arrangements, the estimated overall effect of these measures will be an eventual ongoing saving in Budget outlays of the order of $560m.

I do not know whether that was true, even with the heavy qualification, but it does not matter very much. The point is the qualification. No doubt that discredited former Government, in its characteristically devious way, hoped that the public would be fooled by that figure and would interpret it to mean that the Government had taken $560m off next year's outlays. It meant no such thing. If it meant anything at all, it meant that the Government had made some adjustments to policy as a result of which at some time in the future, over an indefinite number of Budgets, outlays would be reduced by $560m.

I made the comparison earlier with the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. The eventual ongoing saving in Budget outlays-to use the former Prime Minister's words-attributable to cancelling that decision was almost $500m, but the Budget savings for the year in which it was cancelled were, from memory, of the order of $10m. The actual savings in projected outlays in the 1981-82 Budget from the Fraser Government's razor gang exercise, given that they were never stated, were probably of the order of $10m, $20m or, if one is generous, $50m; certainly nowhere near $500m. If it had been anywhere near $500m or $560m, it would have been quantified and specified.

I have some sympathy for Senator Chaney as he was a member of that Government and, I believe, one of its more, if not most, responsible Ministers. But he suffers from a bit of pique and jealousy because the best that that Government could produce was an unspecified and undetailed assertion that $560m had been saved over an unknown period in an unknown number of Budgets from adjustments to an unknown number of programs, the financial consequences of which were not quantified. I can understand Senator Chaney being a bit piqued that, given the puerile and pathetic effort of the Government of which he was a member for that result, this Government is about to deliver a figure and an outcome that really mean something.

Senator Chaney also referred to the deficit-I think the term that I almost always use is 'prospective deficit'-inherited by this Government of $9.6 billion, incorporating a deflator which was not unrealistic as the estimates of outlays produced one year later showed. That was a real figure, a prospective $9.6 billion deficit. That is what this Government inherited and that is what the previous Government had denied in the week before the election. On both the Tuesday and the Friday prior to the March 1983 election the discredited former Treasurer had asserted that the Budget deficit for 1983-84 would be of the order of $6 billion, when he had been told that the correct figure was $9.6 billion. He had been told the correct figure yet he publicly asserted that it was $6 billion. He was up to his neck in the conspiracy with the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, to deceive the people of Australia. That is the man whom Senator Chaney would have as an alternative Prime Minister and that is the man whom the Opposition would have as an alternative Treasurer.

If one looks at his record as Treasurer, one sees that it is marginally better than his record as a fearless and frank discloser of truth in the week before an election. Mr Howard presided over five Budgets. The errors in outlays for the first three of those Budgets were within reasonable bounds because nobody can predict outlays with any real precision, even if there is no intention to do otherwise. But in his last two years, his record deteriorated rapidly. In his second last Budget the error in actual outlays outcome as compared to projections was $463m and in the last year it exploded to a massive $1,915m-almost a $2 billion error in the estimates of outlays. If outlays figures containing errors of that magnitude were to be consistently published, one could argue that they would not be of much enlightenment to anybody, as indeed the outlays figures published early in 1984 were not very enlightening, given the erroneous deflator figure that had been built into them.

If one looks at the deviation between forecast deficits and actual outcomes produced by the previous Treasurer, one sees much the same pattern emerge. His first Budget of 1978-79 had a deficit $665m higher than he had projected. That is substantial but it is acceptable. It is not so wildly at variance with the predicted deficit that one could say that a prima facie case had been made for either gross incompetence or worse. In 1979-80 he got closer. In 1980-81 he was also reasonably close, in fact, somewhat closer. Then, the rot set in. It was the same old pattern, not only of increasing magnitudes of error, but of the changes always going in the same direction. In 1980-81 his Budget deficit was in fact $400m lower than had been projected. In 1981-82 it was $450m higher. So in one year some $850m had been added in the direction of an understatement of the deficit. But that was nothing compared to what was to come. In his last Budget the deficit which he estimated was understated in comparison with the final outcome by $2,799m, which even exceeded, in absolute terms, the error of his outlays estimate.

Finally, Senator Chaney was critical of me for-to use his emotive and misleading language-'attempting to blackmail the Opposition' into not criticising the Government on the grounds that it would destabilise the economy, the dollar and so on. Under normal circumstances that might be a reasonable comment to make. Under these circumstances, however, it is not. It is not because the people who are in charge of this Opposition, or rather its Leader, have an established record of economic sabotage for perceived political gain. In the two weeks before the 1983 election he shouted to the world that if Labor won government there would be a massive devaluation of the dollar. Because of his economic sabotage there was a flight of capital from the country followed by a devaluation of the dollar-the self-fulfilling prophecy which that opportunist Leader of the Opposition, with no scruples at all, employed for perceived political gain as a result of which Australian taxpayers were defrauded of hundreds of millions of dollars by foreign currency speculators. That is the sort of thing that this Opposition continues to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a motion that, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to provide adequate information to enable proper judgment to be made of its economic policies.

This debate is, or should be primarily, about the non-release of forward estimates. That is my understanding of the sort of information that this Senate and this Parliament need to enable them to make their judgments. To put it into context, that is one piece or area of information which the Government has been very disinclined to reveal, not only to the Senate and to Parliament, but to the people of Australia. I find this very hard to understand because it contrasts dramatically with the provision of adequate information by the Government in a lot of other areas. I believe that the Government should be praised for the sort of information that it has provided to the Parliament and to the public at large, in particular the sorts of things that it has done through the economic summit which was followed by the creation of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, which has been a channel of information to the public and to the major decision-makers out there in the private enterprise area. Hopefully, the tax summit will do the same sort of thing.

I also draw a contrast with the sort of information the Government provides through its Ministers and its departments to Australian Democrat senators. In contrast to the forward estimates, that information has been unrestricted; it has been generously given. There has been no door closed to the Democrats in their search for information, whether it be information relating to specific Bills or to other areas of inquiry. I compliment this Government for opening its doors to honourable senators in that way. I am told that this contrasts dramatically with the approach of the Fraser Government, when doors were firmly locked and bolted against Democrat senators in their search for information.

However, we and the public have been kept in the dark and are being kept in the dark about this Government's economic plans and economic strategy. There is no doubt whatsoever in my mind that that is having an effect right across the nation-an effect of uncertainty which goes beyond the nation. Nobody is now sure of the direction the Government may take. This lack of knowledge of the Government's economic plans and strategies is having an effect on the Government itself and on its policies. It is having an effect on the Parliament. The Parliament cannot adequately debate the Government's economic strategies, as indicated by the motion before us. It is probably having an effect on government departments, which are unsure of the nature of cuts and the degree of stringency that may be introduced in the next Budget. It is also having quite an impact on private enterprise because there is a degree of uncertainty in the market-place as to the direction this Government is likely to take in the next few months, the direction it may be compelled to take. Nobody has access to the information on which rational judgments may be made. Private enterprise particularly, including both Australian and overseas investors in private enterprise, needs that information. If we had that information available-I believe that governments do have it available-it should be on a three-year rolling Budget basis and not just an annual forward estimates basis, so that we could see ahead the plans, the strategies of the Government for the people of Australia. We need to bear that in mind. We are not just talking about the Government of Australia.

It is most unfortunate that this Government has recently reverted to a practice, which we have seen over the years and decades, of providing us with inadequate information in this chamber. I think it is fair to name one honourable senator who has been very disappointing. I refer to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who either has been poorly briefed in carrying the Treasury portfolio from time to time or has deliberately denied information to the Senate. I have not been the only person to suffer from this. The Australian Democrats have found it very difficult to get meaningful information in answers from Senator Walsh to questions asked in the Senate. I hope that as a result of this debate he will realise the importance of keeping the Senate and honourable senators informed so that we can make our judgments on legislation and on Budgets that will come before the Parliament.

The Government is again following the patterns of the past. That is very disappointing from a Government which complained bitterly about this pattern but which has refused to reveal information such as the degree of foreign ownership of the assets of this country. That is not something that needs to be kept secret from the people of Australia. I have put a Bill before the Parliament to have created by the Government a register of foreign ownership. It has been studiously ignored so far through two Parliaments. That is typical of the gradual clamping down on information, the clamming up to keep information away from the people who have ultimate responsibility for the decisions that come through this Parliament. We the parliamentarians need to know why we are about to have imposed on us and on the country a May mini-Budget, call it what you will. Today Senator Walsh suggested that he had made forecasts. Two months ago I predicted, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, that we would have a May mini-Budget, and now we are.

It has been revealed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the necessity is there; the belt tightening has to take place. Nobody has been told why it is necessary, other than as an international public relations exercise. We have not been told whether in fact the May expenditure cuts are even necessary. Is it simply to fit in with a planned reduced deficit? If so, we want to know what that planned deficit is to be. It does not make sense to come into this Parliament and just say 'Let us slash $1 billion off the expenditure side of things' without putting it into the context of the total deficit, without our knowing the total estimated expenditure as revised at this month, and without knowing the total estimated revenue as revised at this month. We also need to know what will be the effect on jobs. I will go into that in more detail a little later, but that seems to be one of the critical elements which has not been addressed by anybody-the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Acting Treasurer (Senator Walsh), or anybody on behalf of the Government.

If this is only an international public relations exercise aimed at the international financial markets, and if they do not respond to this dramatic gesture-they have not yet responded as a result of yesterday's announcement-we will get the worst of both worlds. We will finish up with a further devalued dollar and with lower economic activity as a result of withdrawal of funds from the economy. That will lead us into an even more rapidly downward spiralling of the economy. I am willing to accept that there are some benefits from the devaluation which has taken place and is taking place at the moment. One of the benefits this Government seems to want to slide over very quickly is the massive benefit it will get from the petrol price increase. It will get another major benefit. As a result of the increased exports it will have more taxes in its coffers. We have had no estimate of what sorts of benefits to revenue this is likely to bring.

When we do not have that information in front of us, how can we make judgments on whether the expenditure cuts are justified? Why are we having a further $1 billion cut? It cannot be that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been persuaded after all these years by the Fraser rhetoric-which was that a lower deficit would lead to economic recovery-because that has to be one of the most discredited economic theories that has ever been promulgated. Yet that seems to be the sole rationale for this further $1 billion cut in expenditure at this time-just to reduce the deficit.

I am a little surprised that the Government is moving in that direction. Recently we have seen pressure on the Government to forgo petrol price increases. If the Government had been willing to forgo those increases, that would have enabled industry and taxpayers to benefit immediately from the devaluation. We would all have benefited. It would have flowed right through the economy. Why were the pleas ignored? There must have been a reason; but no one knows. What information is the Government withholding which can rationalise what it has done by allowing the import parity pricing policy to continue at this stage of economic development?

It is appreciated that the Australian devaluation has another major benefit overall to the Australian economy. We shall get increased exports from it. We shall have reduced imports from it. That will result in an improved trade balance. So we are getting a lot of pluses out of this devaluation. I think it is accepted, also, that the devaluation itself was necessary. The Australian dollar was over-valued. A float provided the opportunity for it to reach its true value; but at this moment, it has been devalued too far and it is subject to further international pressure. But the market will respond to responsible economic management if it is given the information. There is no need to follow the United States Government policies. The United States has the biggest deficits, both trade and domestic, that the world has known. We do not have to follow down that path.

The Australian Democrats want us to focus on real remedies and be rid of this obsession with the deficit. We believe that the key to Australia's economic revival is getting the rate of employment up and getting interest rates down. The last Fraser deficit resulted directly from the high rate of unemployment. Now we have the problem of how to stimulate the economy through more jobs. Once it is on stream, the economic gnomes will endorse it, and we shall get our increased dollar value, back to its real value.

Interest rates are the crucial ingredient for Australia's economic revival because, next to unemployment, the biggest worry for most Australian's is the interest rate. We had Mr Fraser endeavouring to reduce the deficit, and interest rates skyrocketed. Labor, in the past two governments, has reduced the deficit by $1 billion per annum, so it says, and yet still the interest rates are very high. The real interest rate, the difference between interest charged and the rate of inflation, is now between 8 per cent and 10 per cent, probably the highest that this country has ever had. Home loan interest rates, which have risen 0.5 per cent in the past fortnight, will probably increase further. That is where the concentration needs to be.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting the motion today because we believe that all governments-not just this one-need to provide full information to this Parliament. We believe that the improvement in the provision that we have seen under this Government is not sufficient and that the present Government and any future government will have an obligation, as a result of this motion being carried today, to provide the information that the Parliament needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not very often that we get an opportunity to agree with Senator Jack Evans on economic matters, but I agree with his statement today that the Government has certainly been less than forthcoming in the provision of information to this Parliament and to the people of Australia about the current economic situation in this country. We do not have to look too far in order to determine the reasons for that. There is a simple reason why we had the much vaunted prime ministerial Press conference yesterday, and that is simply that it was a political stunt to try to re-establish some kind of confidence in the Australian dollar. But the very reverse is likely to happen, because the very arguments that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was seeking to advance in his Press conference yesterday can be seen for what they are-shot through with holes like a Swiss cheese. Indeed, they are so vague and so incomplete that no one will trust that information out in the market-place, not least the financial currency traders who today have reacted by putting the Australian dollar down even further.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it that the Government is not seeing fit to release a proper package of information about the forward estimates? During the Press conference yesterday, Mr Hawke was asked whether or not the billion dollars that he says he is saving off the deficit was to be cut from the forward estimates. In a rather confusing answer, he gave us some idea that perhaps they were coming off the forward estimates of expenditures. He said:
. . . forward estimates are not there in a releasable form because what is happening is that we undertook the expenditure review exercise early in this year.

This is apparently an attempt by the Government to tell us that it cannot give us this information because it has been working hard to get the information ready, but it cannot be released to us-we who would be seeking to make decisions upon it. Without going too far into the inherent unreliability and the contradictory nature of that, let us just go on and say that a journalist at the Press conference asked the Prime Minister: 'How do you know that, indeed, you have got a billion dollar reduction if you cannot tell us off which items of expenditure this is coming?' The Prime Minister said: 'We have got the figures'. But indeed, he will not release them. Why is it that the Prime Minister will not release that information so that the market can make up its own mind? I put it to the Senate that one of the chief reasons for that is there in the Prime Minister's statement yesterday. In reply to a journalist's question about why he would not release the information, he said:
. . . the other thing which has affected the forward estimates is the whole volatility of the currency.

Senator Walsh, during his rambling speech, gave us a further hint as to that when he said, sotto voce in answer to an interjection, I think, in connection with the items of expenditure that were not being disclosed, that this would have a dramatic impact upon the Budget itself. This is the reason why we are not being told about the actual items of expenditure that will be affected; because the Prime Minister knows that whatever the estimates are now, they will change substantially as a result of any further changes in the currency, and obviously they may be in a downward direction. That is what he is covering his tracks about. He wants to be able to say something about that in clear terms at a later stage. He does not want to have to own up to it today, and certainly he does not want to admit to it when he is trying to build up some kind of farrago that demonstrates that there really ought to be confidence in the Government when it is clear to the rest of the world and to the Australian people that there is no confidence.

I guess that if all the people in Australia had access to the transcript of the Press conference yesterday, from which I quote, they would get a very clear impression as to what is wrong with this Government. We got an explanation as to why the forward estimates would not be released when the Prime Minister said:

And so the simplest way and the accurate way of putting what we are about is that, put it this way, that in respect of forward that would have existed before we undertook the expenditure review process, these decisions that we are taking represent a cut of at least a billion dollars.

I can see, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you are looking puzzled-and you are not the only one. It is an absolute masterpiece of gobbledegook, and if the financial community of Australia, let alone those of New York, Washington, London, Paris and everywhere else, cannot understand it, it is no wonder that the Australian dollar is collapsing. Because this Government has absolutely no control over what it is doing the country is descending into economic disaster.

Let us examine one or two of the points that were raised by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in the course of his remarks. He continued to purvey the story about the $9.6 billion deficit for 1983-84 that he lay at the door of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard. That, of course, was disowned by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) in Hansard on 2 April last year when he said that the Liberals would have had a deficit of $2 billion to $3 billion less than the deficit last year. Consequently, Senator Walsh's argument falls apart. This was denied even more by the very fact that on 2 July 1984 the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said:
If Mr Fraser had remained in power their Budget deficit would have been about $6.5 billion.

This is at least $3 billion less than what Senator Walsh is claiming would have been the situation. When we and, I believe, the Australian Democrats pushed the Government at this time last year to reveal the forward estimates, the Government would not disclose the information. Why? Because the information was not reliable at that time. That is absolutely remarkable! One year when it suits the Government politically it is reliable and the next year when does not it is not disclosed. What are the people of Australia going to say about the present situation? The Government is prepared to tell us that it will knock a nice round sum, $1,000m, off the deficit but it is not prepared to tell us why and where? What can the people expect? They cannot believe that nonsense, nor are they likely to. That is why the people of Australia have no confidence in this Government.

We ought to have a further look at some of the activities of the present Prime Minister in his role as the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions over many years. It is ironic that in the last two years Mr Hawke has received praise for attempting to solve the very problems that he had a very large part in creating. We know that he was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions from 1969 until 1980. He is now being applauded for licking his self-inflicted wounds. It is an unfashionable fact but Australia's falling competitiveness over the last 26 years has been due in no small part to Mr Hawke's personal success as an advocate for the trade unions in working for the ACTU. For years Mr Hawke advocated higher wages and shorter hours regardless of the implications for Australia and its place in the world economy. It has created what Mr Howard, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, has said is the Hawke factor in unemployment. Max Walsh, writing in the Bulletin, was clever enough to find out about this point when he said.
Hawke's first great arbitration victory was in 1959 when he persuaded the Commission that the policy of wage fixation it had pursued from 1953 was incorrect.
Hawke won a 15 shilling (i.e., 6 per cent) increase in the basic wage and, soon after, went on to win a 28 per cent increase in margins for skill.

That the combination of these victories caused a trebling in the rate of inflation . . . to 3.9 per cent and ushered in the corrective credit squeeze of 1960 was a lesson never understood fully by the Labor movement.

The evidence still is that the Prime Minister, now in his other role, has not learned that lesson yet. In 1970 Mr Hawke proclaimed that 1971 would be the year of the 35-hour week in Australia. There was no talk then of productivity deals; the demand was for more pay and less work. In 1974 Mr Hawke severely criticised the Whitlam Government-we know how free that Government was-for opposing a 27 per cent wage increase for airline pilots. Around this time he expressed the ACTU's policy on wages as follows:

We know inflation is at 16 per cent and we believe it's quite likely to reach 20 per cent in the next two quarters. But we will not indulge in a trade-off in wages for some conjectural reduction in inflation.

He took great issue with the Whitlam Government in 1975 and opposed full wage indexation and claimed that on top of indexation the unions should be able to bargain for wage increases. It is little wonder that Mr Hawke came in for criticism from former Senator Jim McClelland, a Minister of the Labor Government at that time. He summed up Mr Hawke's attitude as follows:
I remember him saying to me. 'Yes, we'll cop wage indexation but only if we can get anything else we want on top of that'.

This is the man who claims to have invented wages moderation. Is it any wonder that the people of Australia cannot believe him and that the Australian dollar is falling so dramatically? Mr Hawke's record on wages is absolutely appalling. We know that. He has the temerity today to claim that most of the problems that are occurring in the economy today are due to the actions of conservative governments over the last 35 years. I will quote some figures on the increases in average weekly earnings for the years 1966 to 1972. The nominal increase in wages during the period of the Holt, Gorton and McMahon governments was 8.3 per cent. From 1972 to 1975, when Mr Hawke had a great deal of influence over the trade union movement and was pushing wages higher and higher, that figure was 18.6 per cent. In the years 1975 to 1983, in the period of office of the Fraser Government, it dropped to 11.3 per cent and under the Hawke Government it is now 7.9 per cent. The point is that the rate of increase was most significant when driven by the activities of the previous President of the ACTU in his former role.

Let us take one or two other government expenditure figures to demonstrate the truth of this argument. If we compare the growth in real Budget outlays with gross domestic product increases we will see that under the Menzies Government there was an increase in outlays of 3.2 per cent compared with a growth rate of 4.7 per cent. Under the McMahon Government there was an increase of 3.9 per cent, but a growth rate of 4.5 per cent in the economy. Under the Whitlam Government the reverse occurred; there was an increase in outlays of 11.1 per cent and a growth in the economy of only 2.8 per cent. Under the Hawke Government there was an increase in Budget outlays, of expenditures, of 7.1 per cent whereas there has been a growth in the economy of only 5.3 per cent. This is a disaster. How can the people of Australia believe Mr Hawke when he comes out with a farrago such as he put forward yesterday?

In conclusion I will mention a pertinent comment made in the Syntec edition of 1 April 1985. I do not have time to read it all. Syntec states that there has been a process of winking and nodding. The Government should wake up to itself and seek to gain the confidence of the community again. It can start this right now by providing straightforward, honest and direct information so that Australians and those overseas who are making decisions about our markets can form their well based opinions on the Government's policies and intentions in place of the fumbles, farragoes and falsehoods that the Prime Minister sought to push on the Australian people yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray said that this is a pious motion. That statement is typical of the lack of understanding by members on the Government side of just what is going on in the Australian economy and of some of the reasons why it is going on. This debate is all about the fact that the Government has provided totally deficient information on key areas for which it has responsibility and on which depends, importantly, the very health of the Australian economy. As a result of this deficiency in information, confidence within the Australian business community is flagging rapidly. As well the international community is registering its concern by continuing to push the value of the Australian dollar down to almost daily record lows. Confidence can be a self-sustaining process but so too can falling confidence. I warn the Government that unless it takes urgent steps to stem the tide it will be too late. There is no doubt at all that in the business community both here and abroad there is increasing concern about the direction in which the Government's economic policies are heading. There is a growing feeling that the Government is rudderless and leaderless. The attempts of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to shore up the situation a couple of weeks ago by going on national television and asserting that the Government was in control of the economy only made matters worse. As soon as a leader goes public and proclaims 'I am in control', people will, very correctly, draw only one conclusion-that he is not in control.

SPEECH.PARA: So what should the Government do? It should do several things, and the first is that when it does provide information it should not provide it on a selective basis to privileged groups. Information is selectively available to one group which the Government has placed in a totally privileged position, and that is the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The ACTU was quite improperly provided with economic data before the finalisation of the 1984 Budget. It was provided with and consulted on data and that data was available on a basis which did not apply to any other section of the Australian community. It appears now that a similar sort of process is occurring, although cloaked in apparent secrecy, in terms of the negotiations between the ACTU and the Government on tax reform. I simply make the point that if it is good enough to give information to some groups in the community, it must not be done selectively.

The second thing that the Government should do is not be selective as to when it releases specific information. I refer particularly to its release of forward estimates figures. In 1983, immediately after winning government, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) released what purported to be the estimates of forward expenditure and forward revenue for the defeated Fraser Government. Those two sets of estimates were totally misleading. As Senator Chaney and others have already pointed out in this debate, comparing those two sets of figures, particularly the revenue figures, is totally misleading. The Labor Government did that and later in 1983 it released its own forward expenditure estimates. It did so again in 1984. This year it refuses to do so.

The obvious question is why, and the obvious answer is that there is a major split within the Government on this issue. There is yet another split, and this time it is not even on a factional basis. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has said several times that it would be his intention to release the estimates. On the other hand the Treasurer has said no. That great strong leader, the Prime Minister, again has vacillated and has refused to make a decision, to adjudicate. The real point I want to make is that if it was good enough for the Government to release the figures in 1983 and again in 1984, why should it not do so again in 1985? The only logical conclusion that one can draw is that the Government has something to hide; that it deliberately wants to deceive or at the very least confuse the Australian community.

Without having the forward estimates available it is not possible to judge the worth or otherwise of yesterday's Press statement by the Prime Minister announcing so-called expenditure cuts of $1 billion in 1985-86. What does that figure and the Prime Minister's statement mean? For a start, the fact that he did not make the statement in Parliament when Parliament itself was sitting suggests either an incredible contempt for the Parliament or that his statement is nothing more than another dose of the windy rhetoric that has become the trademark of this Government. On the face of it, the so-called expenditure cut means virtually nothing. It is a cut of $1 billion, but $1 billion off what? Is it $1 billion off $50 billion, $60 billion or $70 billion? Is it less of a cut-and it appears to be, as the Minister for Finance was forced to acknowledge today-off the forward estimates than was the case in each of the last two years?

So what is this $1 billion all about? It is simply not possible to say, until we have much more information. What will be the currency impact? What will be the effect of the devaluation in terms of government expenditure within that $1 billion dollar context? Again that question was asked today and again it was not answered. Even in the last two years, when the reduction in the forward estimates spending was greater than has been announced for this year, when the Budgets finally came out we had real increases in spending at a rate which approached the horrifying and crippling increases of the Whitlam years. The average real expenditure increase by this Government in its last two Budgets has been 7 per cent. That is not far short of the real increases that occurred during the years of the Whitlam Government and it is more than three times the rate of increase in government spending that occurred during the whole of the average of the seven years of the Fraser Government, despite the fact that in two of those years we had significant increases in spending. As a result of what has happened in the last two Budgets, with near record increases in spending, we have also had record increases in taxation and in government borrowings. We are now more highly taxed and more highly borrowed and have the highest real interest rates in our history.

I wish Senator Walsh well in this attempt to reduce government expenditure. All I can say is that his attempts to date appear to have failed miserably, but-this is the point-we simply do not have enough information to make a judgment. That is the reason for today's debate and the reason why the motion before the Senate today is an urgency motion. I also say to Senator Walsh that if he is not successful, if he does not reduce the rate of increase in government spending to zero or near zero, and if he does not reduce the Budget deficit to a maximum of $5 billion, the Government will lose all credibility within the Australian and international communities and the result on our economy will be horrendous.

I refer the House to reports in today's Press of the visit to Australia by Mr Peter Grace, who is President Reagan's adviser on cost cutting. In Melbourne yesterday he said that America was on a straight course to national bankruptcy, constituting the unforgiveable rape of future generations, and that Australia was in an even worse position. He said that students should riot and parade in the streets about this. What he was really talking about was the wasteful expenditure by governments in America and Australia and the effect that has on Budget deficits and therefore the putting into hock of future generations. It is absolutely crucial, not just for the health of the Australian economy today but for the future health of the economy and the well-being of future generations in Australia, that we get our government finances much more in order.

There are other very important issues on which the Government is simply not coming clean. Why does the Government not recognise publicly that the devaluation of the dollar, which has occurred largely as a result of this Government, means automatically a fall in our real gross national product and that it therefore requires a fall in real wages if the potential benefits of the devaluation are to be reaped? The Prime Minister referred to it obliquely in his Press statement yesterday but he was not prepared to come clean with the necessary consequences in relation to real wages. On the AM program this morning the Prime Minister refused to acknowledge that the belt-tightening, which both he and the Treasurer very correctly say is necessary, has to flow through to a reduction in real wages. It is absolutely essential that the Government make it known very soon that it will seek to have the devaluation effects on the consumer price index excluded from the next national wage case. If the Government refuses to do this it is abrogating its responsibilities in what is undoubtedly a key issue of the economy. The depreciation of over 20 per cent in the value of the Australian dollar over the last three months represents a cut of something like 4 per cent in the real value of the Australian national product. Whether the trade unions, or anyone else for that matter, like it or not, Australia is now a poorer country than it was three months ago. That in turn implies the necessity of a cut of the same order, on average, in real returns to all factors of production. Clearly, the Government needs to tell the ACTU and the rest of the community very firmly that we can no longer, in these changed circumstances, support the full indexation of wage rates. The Government, and the Prime Minister in particular, are refusing to bite the bullet on this issue.

Another key area in which the Government is not coming clean is the area of monetary policy. We need information on the Government's monetary policy. What is the policy? Why did the Government not come forward much earlier and say that it was deliberately pushing up interest rates to the highest real level in Australia's history to prop up the Australian dollar, at a time when the dollar has been falling as a result of the policies of this Government, and there has been international loss of confidence in this Government? Why did the Government abandon its monetary targets earlier this year and why has it refused to introduce new targets? The Prime Minister missed a golden opportunity yesterday, when making his statement on expenditure, to say something about monetary policy and monetary targets. I urge him to do so in his May statement.

The primary need is to restore a clear monetary target by which the performance of the Government can be judged. There has been too much deliberate fudging of the policy issues by emphasising the current problems of interpretation of particular monetary growth figures. It would give great confidence to the business community in particular if monetary targets for the next 12 to 15 months were established very quickly and announced, and there is no earthly reason why that should not be done. The Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, is reported to have told union colleagues recently that the Government is lacking vision and has lost direction. I heartily agree, but it has also lost the capacity to be honest with the Australian public. It is unwilling to take the Australian public into its confidence and, as a result, it is losing the confidence of the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the matter of urgency brought down by Senator Chaney, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to provide adequate information to enable proper judgment to be made of its economic policies.

I wanted to read out the subject of the motion because judging from the last few contributions from the Opposition, I think it has lost its way in attempting to follow the lead set by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). That a member of the Liberal Party of Australia could move such a matter of urgency in this chamber is, of course, demonstrative of the extraordinary effrontery and gall it continues to show. I should have thought that a member of the Party which perpetrated upon the people of Australia the great lie and frustrated the provision of information to enable proper judgment to be made who moves a motion such as this must have a pretty awful memory.

The very first thing with which the Hawke Government was confronted when it took office in early 1983 was the great lie about the size of the deficit. We came into office having been told that the deficit was going to be $6 billion. Within a matter of weeks-indeed I think within only two weeks-it was pretty obvious to the Government that, as the figures showed, because expenditure had at no stage been reined in the Budget deficit was going to come in at $9.6 billion. Yet the same Party that perpetrated this great lie upon the Australian people, in a deliberate attempt to frustrate proper judgment being made of what it had been up to, in the words of this motion, comes in today with this matter of urgency.

One comes up with another inevitable conclusion from some of the contributions by the Opposition. After two years and some months in opposition, the once great Liberal Party that ruled Australia for so long has suddenly realised that the born to rule mantle its members put upon themselves is gradually coming apart. No longer are they sitting in positions of power from which they can dole out, miserably, bits of information from time to time. Suddenly they are confronted with the sad spectacle of being on the other side, of having to wear whatever the Government is prepared to dole out to them. Obviously that is not sitting easily upon their shoulders. Those anxious to get into government, anxious to be sitting on ministerial seats, are finding that the distance between themselves and the ministerial seats gets greater and greater every day.

The Opposition must have been terrified when the Hawke Government took office that it would adopt the same stance as the Fraser Government adopted in regard to the way it handled the dissemination of information to enable judgments to be made on economic policies. Fortunately for the Liberal Party and the National Party, they would have discovered within the early months of the Hawke Government that that was not to be the case. If the Opposition had had any doubt about the sort of government the Hawke Government was going to be, and how it would handle the dissemination of information, it had only to await the first economic summit, which took place in the House of Representatives chamber only two years ago. There, for the first time, the Hawke Government established that it would share information with all sections of our community, with the trade unions, with those representing the poor, with business-with everybody-to make sure that enough information was on the table for us all to make deliberate and rational judgments.

However, it must be said-I would like it put into the record of Hansard very early in the piece-that enough figures must be around for senior Opposition spokespersons to make judgments. Indeed, I am sure that members of the Opposition would not be prepared to believe that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, would in any way not be able to make a proper judgment. I quote from a Press release by John Howard of just a few days ago. Commenting on the publication of the national accounts figures for the December quarter he said:

I welcome the economic growth disclosed by the December quarter national accounts figures. They indicate that for the year to December 1984 overall growth was 4.6 per cent with non-farm growth being at 5.1 per cent. This is good economic news for Australia.

They are the real statements I would like members of the Opposition to take into account. If one had listened to what has occurred here over the last couple of hours one would not have heard much acknowledgment of the real benefit and good done by the Hawke Government. I am pleased to see that John Howard, at least, was prepared to recognise it over the last few days. The matter of urgency attempts to refer to two areas. The first is the question of whether forward estimates should be published. The second is whether the suspension of monetary targeting, however temporary it may have been, may have upset members of the Opposition. Let us look at the first area. The reality is that no decision has yet been taken as to whether the forward estimates will be published. After the Government has put forward its May statement, a decision will be taken on this matter. As I understand it, the Prime Minister reiterated today that it is still within the realms of possibility that those figures will be published.

The benefit to be gained from the publication of the forward estimates has, however, been completely taken away by the Government's announced policy on the trilogy. That represents an unprecedented discipline on this Government and, indeed, would have done on any previous government, insofar as finance is concerned. It is a commitment, a forward indication of fiscal policy, the clearest commitment ever given by an Australian government. It commits the Government to hold outlays growth and receipts growth to the growth in gross domestic product. Furthermore and, I think, most importantly judging by the contributions of those opposite, it commits the Government to reduce the deficit in money terms. If one is to reduce the deficit, obviously one has to look at outlays. In the last few days the Government has given the clearest indication I can remember in decades of what it is going to do about outlays. The Prime Minister's statement yesterday about the cuts of $1 billion must have given those opposite some idea of the Government's target. The statement yesterday was made so that people can make a proper judgment about economic policies.

Forward estimates, as we all know, are not a reliable guide either to total expenditure in the years ahead or to spending on specific programs. Ministers, whether at Expenditure Review Committee meetings or in Cabinet, have to go through those estimates and make decisions on cuts. They make changes. Things are altered up or down. In the end one comes out with the Government's decisions. The targets have already been revealed. The trilogy which we have announced our commitment to and which we will keep is the real information the Opposition needs. I will get to monetary targets later. First, I mention the question of Budget deficits. I am staggered by the fact that anyone opposite could raise the question, given the performance of the Opposition in the last election campaign. One does not have to go back to the Fraser years. One has only to look at Andrew Peacock's performance when he was promising all and sundry anything they wanted during the last election campaign. A quick rundown of promises suggests that more than $10 billion would have been added to the deficit last year if the Opposition had been elected to office. We would have had a deficit of $17 billion. All talk of fiscal responsibility went out the window. The ridiculous claim in the first place that ordinary families were $22 worse off and that their position would be immediately restored would have added $6 billion before one got to anything else. The figures I have just outlined do not even include any reference to what it would cost for the Darwin to Alice Springs railway, the other promise which was trotted out towards the end of the campaign and which would have cost more than $1 billion to implement. That sort of fiscal irresponsibility is too much for any country to handle. This country certainly could not handle it.

Whatever the position of this Government on providing economic information, it is an awful long way in front of what the Opposition doled out when it was in government. During the seven years of office of the Fraser Government I cannot remember information flowing out of the place; there was not even a trickle. Let us look at the $1 billion expenditure cuts that were announced yesterday. One has to go back to the period of the Lynch razor gang in, I think, 1981 to look at any claim by the Opposition about its intentions. The Lynch razor gang finally announced cuts of $560m. We announced cuts yesterday of $1 billion. Yet of the $560m in cuts announced by the Lynch razor gang, less than half was ever gone on with. Less than half of the promises of the Lynch razor gang were ever attempted in expenditure cuts. The Opposition never showed a commitment to being prepared to cut expenditure. Yesterday, the Prime Minister made what was an announcement of great importance, that finally this Government is about expenditure cuts. We have announced $1 billion worth of cuts.

To the extent that this mater of urgency reflects the complaint about the abolition of monetary targeting, all one has to do is concede-it is a concession that most, if not all, of the financial pundits around the country have already made-that the momentum caused by the movement from non-bank to bank institutions, because of the deregulation we introduced over the last few months, has distorted any possibility of getting proper monetary targets, at least in the intermediate period. The Government has not said at any stage that monetary targets are abolished for all time. All the Government has said is that for the foreseeable future, that is, for the next six months, while the movement for non-bank to bank institutions takes place because of this Government's policies on deregulation-policies so often talked about but never acted upon by its predecessors-monetary targeting had to be done away with. That does not mean for a moment that the Government has moved away from its non-inflationary monetary policy. It could not do that. It will not do that. No amount of complaints by the Opposition would ever bring the Government to do so.

I return to those words about providing adequate information. The Government's purpose for a very long time has been to insist upon that sharing of information in a wide range of areas. First, the Economic Planning Advisory Council, which the Liberal Party has promised to disband, has had a very significant effect in Australia for some time now. Information sharing has been going on at EPAC since its formation over two years ago. The Construction Industry Council set up by the Government, and the Australian Mining Industry Council-in all there are 11 industry councils-are further examples of bodies with which the Government is sharing information. We have the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which took a long time to bring about by careful negotiation, information sharing and consultation, which is the hallmark of the Hawke Government. It has meant that wage growth has been contained for the first time in many years. One only has to go back four years to see that in one year of the Fraser Government wages growth was 17 per cent. By consultation and sharing information with the ACTU the Government has kept wage growth down to a 2.6 per cent increase in 12 months.

In the housing industry the Government set up the Construction Forecasting Committee in 1983. In the housing industry, home dwellings commencement have grown from 105,000 to 150,000 in just two years. That is the sort of policy this Government is about. It has brought about a huge growth in home starts, new jobs and new confidence in that field. All that was done while material prices stayed fairly flat. They were not forced up and there was more non-inflationary growth.

This debate ought to be about growth. The Government is counting on growth with its trilogy, and it is growth that will see Australia come out of its uncompetitive position. In the last year we have had real growth of 5.7 per cent with 4 per cent from the non-farm sector. That is what this Government promised to deliver and it is what we have had. In fact, we have had more growth than any other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. There ought to be some acknowledgment from the Opposition in this chamber that the Government's economic policies have worked. If we are worried about the fall in the value of the dollar, doomsday predictions arising from past failures ought not to be the way we judge the matter. We ought to judge it on the real figures, which show that Australian is going ahead once again.
